text: well let's bring in the bbc's lisa set
our chief international correspondent
who's live with us from kabul lee thanks
for joining us
is it remotely realistic for everyone
who wants to leave to get out by the end
of the month
roz
i love to be able to answer all your
questions but that is one
i simply cannot answer we do not know
how many people want to get out by the
end of the month you just heard my
colleague sir under carmani surrounded
by people when he went to the gate
begging him for help my mobile telephone
and i'm just one person
of people the world over who are being
sent sos messages every day by the hour
sometimes i'm receiving them almost
every minute please can you put me on a
list please can you get me to the
airport please my life is in danger
please give me some advice as the news
spreads that people
who don't have a seat on the flight who
don't have a position on the list are
still able to get through even though i
think that's not the case people are
going to the airport just to test their
luck because they know this window as
you've been saying is going to close and
i spent most of the last 24 hours at
that airport both on the military and on
the civilian side and i can tell you
at every single gate there is a crush of
people
desperate to get in to try and get on a
flight to anywhere in the world even
though this is such a painful time so
many of the people we met roz broke down
in tears that this has happened all so
suddenly all so shockingly that they
don't want to leave their lives are here
but they feel that if they ever had the
idea for either for themselves or for
their children to leave that this is the
moment and that when that window shuts
it may shut forever for them
and leave we have this desperate
situation at the airport a looming
deadline and now we have the taliban
saying this has to be finished by the
31st of august those troops need to go
what's the taliban saying about what it
will do
if that doesn't happen
i think i should also emphasize roz that
even though these images uh and they are
such stark uh images going around the
world of thousands trying to leave there
are millions who will stay in
afghanistan that's in the double digits
of millions some because they don't want
to leave others because they simply
don't have a way to leave and so for
them of course uh they're much more
invested in the future of afghanistan
and they of course want to know what
kind of new islamic emirate the taliban
are establishing so let me just respond
though to your question about the
august the 31st deadline that came from
suhel shaheen he is the taliban
spokesperson for english media his job
is to reflect the decisions of the
leadership that is the leader signed a
deal with the united states the u.s
troops were supposed to leave by may the
first and when the u.s led nato forces
didn't lead we heard the taliban
time and again even after may 1st had
long passed saying that all the forces
should have left me the first so the new
deadline which they accepted is august
the 31st so again they're saying we want
you to stick by this agreement that we
struck with you
now do they want to have a confrontation
with the united states at the 11th hour
we don't think so and so while they're
officially mentioning the line we do
know that behind the scenes senior
taliban leaders are talking to the
americans are talking to other countries
about whether or not just a few days
more will matter the taliban have been
very critical of all these people trying
to leave the country they've asked them
to stay so they don't feel invested at
all in what's happening in the airport
they don't really mind the chaotic
images uh that may be that they are
being painted of the americans but they
do want to be fully in control of their
country and right now their main
international airport is in the hands of
the americans
lise i'm short on time but i must ask
you before you go you know kabul so well
you've reported on outside source from
kabul many many times how has it changed
from all of those previous visits to how
you see it now
you know as when we we left finally left
the airport this morning and went out
from such a familiar scene the airport
where you have the picture of the
president which of course last one was
ashraf ghani now that's torn
to shreds you have the i love kabul sign
now it's you know the one of those every
city has with the big hearts it's still
there but it's surrounded by razor wire
and american troops but you go out and
you confront the taliban many of them
wearing american-issued uniforms
carrying american-made m4 rifles
carrying those exactly the way americans
would teach you and so that is really
jarring
but i was waiting to see the entrance to
the airport i have always seen that as a
barometer of what is happening in the
city and the country beyond in november
2001 when we left that airport as the
taliban were as we ended yet as the
taliban were on the run kabul was a
desolate city in darkness but year after
year i've seen these thicket of
billboards right at the entrance of the
airport first it was all of the shiny
mobile telephones in a country where
there wasn't one international telephone
line when the taliban were ousted then
it was the big billboards of afghan
politicians urging afghans to vote for
them then there was huge billboards
urging afghans to be patriotic to
support the afghan security forces
what are going to be the billboards now
ross what will be the main messages on
those hoardings as you leave kabul
airport and it says welcome to kabul
today i saw the daily life the sugar
cane juice cellars the boys with you
know tin little tin cans waving incense
buy a bit of positive spirit for a price
and through all these crowds we're
waving the new flag of afghanistan the
white taliban flag
please we also appreciate you coming on
thank you very much indeed this leads to
